body:
Change management is the process of introducing a long-term transition, change or development in an organisation.

In this module, we’ll explore why it is important for organisations to manage the process of change, some key elements of a successful change management process and how to measure the impact of change.
title: Data Change

body:
In this module we’ll explore the following:
  • What is change management?
  • Why is managing change important?
  • What are the key elements of change management?
  • How can we measure change?

Change management is the process of introducing a long-term transition, change or development in an organisation.

The ultimate goal of change management is to change how the organisation operates in the long-term. From adapting its systems, processes and structures, to changing how people within it think and act.

Change management is equally relevant to the public and the private sector, and to organisations both large and small.
title: What is change management?

body: Effective management is essential for the success of any project or initiative. Change management is no exception. Below we explore some of the key reasons why we need to manage the process of change.
title: Why is managing change important?

_items.title: Change doesn't happen overnight
_items.body:
It is almost impossible to implement change overnight, especially in large organisations. Over time, organisations get used to operating in a certain way and it takes time to change those ways.

As implementing change takes time, there needs to be a person, or a team of people, who are dedicated to overseeing and managing the change process. This also serves to ensure that the process continues.

When the UK Government was introducing the country’s open data initiative, they appointed a ‘change team’ to oversee the process. This team provided support to different departments across the organisation and helped them meet their new commitments.

_items.title: Reducing risk
_items.body:
Managing the process of change reduces the overall risks to an organisation.

There are different reasons why an organisation wishes to implement a change management process. Sometimes this can be due to negative impacts from their current process, system, structure or way of working.

In these cases, it is a risk to maintain the current situation as it might lead to a loss in revenue, decline in customer satisfaction, or a decline in the organisation's reputation.

However, it might be equally risky to implement change too quickly. Managing the change process is a way to control these risks and make sure that the change is positive.

_items.title: Ensuring sustainability
_items.body:
Managing the process of change is critical for its sustainability. Having a clear leader who is managing the change process means that the change is more likely to be sustainable long term. This doesn't necessarily have to be the most senior person in the organisation, but they do need to be able to make decisions.

They appoint others to drive the change alongside them who have the necessary skills and responsibilities to make alterations in how the organisation works.

It is also part of this role to ensure that others, both internal and external to the organisation, understand why the change is needed and that they support that change. Without this support, any change is unlikely to be sustainable.

body: There are several key elements necessary to successfully manage change within an organisation. These elements are relevant to both the private and the public sectors.
displayTitle: What are the key elements of change management?
title: What are the key elements of change management?

_items.title: Clear vision
_items.body:
A clear vision is important for change management in order to get internal and external support for the initiative. This vision should align to the organisation's goals, otherwise it will jar with the brand or image of the organisation.

The leader of the project needs to be able to articulate this vision to ensure support internally and externally.

For instance, agricultural company Syngenta issued a ‘Good Growth Plan’ to guide their change management process. The plan provided six significant commitments that guided the process. This plan helped explain the reasons for the change and how they would be introduced.

Take me to Syngenta’s Good Growth Plan

_items.title: Senior buy-in
_items.body:
With any programme of change, it is common for those driving it to meet some resistance from within their organisations.

Active support from senior figures can help to encourage institutional buy-in.

Working with these senior figures is critical, as an ‘insurgency strategy’ to introduce change will not be sustainable.

_items.title: Keeping on track
_items.body:
Organisations big and small need to include metrics or Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) to evaluate the programme's progress. This will help justify investment of time and money in the change programme.

When designing KPIs, think about what will have the most impact. It is useful to include a baseline to compare what the initiative has achieved to what would have been done without the initiative.

There should ideally be three different metrics and focused around the percentage of change that has occurred in a particular case or sector.

_items.title: Communicating impact
_items.body:
Understanding the impact of a change process will help to secure its future.

Those driving forward a change programme should focus on the tangible impact that is a direct result of the programme. A good place to focus is quick wins: areas where low effort will result in immediate impact.

Clearly communicating impact stories will help gain support from all those involved in the programme.

When the Mexican government wanted to increase the impact of their open data initiative, they concentrated on finding ‘quick wins’. These provided clear examples of open data’s impact, and helped get more people on board with the change. As a result, they were able to open up 100 datasets in 42 days across 10 federal agencies.

Take me to the Maxico case study

body:
Measuring change provides a clear benchmark for observers within and outside of the organisation to see the impact. It is important to define what is being measured, how it is being measured and reasonable expectations for the change.

The metrics or KPIs that you choose will depend on your change programme. Amongst others, they could be improvements in efficiency, a better consumer experience, a reduction in complaints or an increased customer base. Choose a metric that makes sense for your organisation, and makes it easy for you to demonstrate the impact of the change that you have introduced.

For example, professional services firm Arup recently changed its business model to partner more closely with open data startups. This experimental approach meant KPIs had to be more loosely defined to allow the company to be quick and responsive to change.

Take me to the Arup case study
title: How can we measure change?

body:
Change management is the process of introducing a long-term transition, change or development in an organisation. Effective management is essential for the success of any project or initiative, and a programme of change is no different.

Key elements of a successful programme of change include clear ownership and vision, senior buy-in, measuring success through clear metrics and communicating that impact.

In the context of Sainsburys, using the principles of change management will help to develop a data sharing for the organisation. Find out more about data sharing and data strategy at Sainsburys.
